body: THERE is nothing circuitous about Flatbush Avenue. It cuts a long and almost direct swath through thec enter of Brooklyn from the Manhattan Bridge to the Belt Parkway. A long the way, it passes neighborhoods that have been in flux for d ecades. Change in neighborhoods and change in regional shopping patterns lead to evolution in the commercial life
title: FLATBUSH AVENUE TAKES ON NEW IDENTITY

body: New York City officials said yesterday that they had arranged to underwrite the construction of 435 single-family homes for low- and moderate-income families in three rundown Brooklyn neighborhoods by combining Federal funds with loans from city pension funds. Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is a pension-fund trustee, said he thought it was the
title: CITY UNDERWRITES PROJECT FOR 435 BROOKLYN HOUSES

body: A 12-year-old boy was stabbed to death and his 10-year-old sister was seriously wounded yesterday afternoon by an intruder who crawled into their Brooklyn apartment through a garbage chute and attacked them as they screamed for help, the police said. The police arrested Albert Lang, a 28-year-old unemployed man who had been living, without paying
title: Intruder Kills Boy, 12, And Wounds Sister, 10

body: The sprint-relay team of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn took two victories today in the 42d annual Eddy Games on the new Union College track here. The quartet of Roger Hunter, Bradley Henry, Adrian Spooner and Rick Amezquita won the 400-meter event in 42.99 seconds and the 1,600-meter event in 3 minutes 19.50 seconds. Hunter, a junior who
title: 2 Relays Won by Jefferson

body: Besides the Kips Bay Boys' Club Show House, which opens this week, there are many other designer showcases and house tours taking place in the next month. All of the tours are self-guided, with maps, and go on rain or shine. Showcases April 29-May 31. Thirty-five rooms at Castles on the Sound, the former Gould/Guggenheim estate in Sands Point,
title: MAY OFFERS A WEALTH OF HOUSE TOURS AND DESIGNER SHOWCASES

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses.
